content.description:
The problem climbs a rough, solid arete over a decent landing.

Sit start matched on a fabulous edge. From there, achieve decent footing, stick a right hand dimple on the arete, adjust the feet, crossover with the left hand to a good edge, then either continue along the arete's edges to the lip or cut back to a nice shelf and the eventual lip.
content.protection: At least a pair of pads. The landing has a few rocks throughout but nothing too bad.
content.location: It climbs the northeast arete of Sand Shark.

content.description: Stand start with high hands on sloping features. From there, throw a heel hook on, gain a left hand sloping edge, follow to the lip, and mantel atop the boulder.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The landing is very good though.
content.location: It climbs the northwest face of Sand Shark.

content.description:
Start with a left hand sidepull crimp and a right hand on a good ledge. With a drop knee, head to the obvious hold. This is possibly the crux according to some who have tried it. I found the next move out of the roof the hardest.

From there, hit the sloper with the left, a sloping crimp with the right, and head to the rail just below the top.

Top out.
content.protection: A couple of pads are good. The landing, even from the beginning, is really uneven and lends itself to making the climber roll or tumble.
content.location: It is located on the north, overhanging face of the Sand Shark Block. There's a downclimb on the west side.
